page.title: 18Folklore of N.E. Longmynd
page.content: Stories handed down from generation to generation are of great interest to both local people and visitors alike. In Leebotwood they tell of a White Lady. During the Civil War, a local gentlewoman lost both her husband and son, and ever since she has walked the area, dressed in white, searching for her loved ones. In 1760 all grazing rights in a local valley were forfeit because a man found dead there had not been sent for burial.To this day the valley is known as 'Dead Man's Batch'. In the great snowstorm of 1865 the Rev. Carr was returning to Woolstaston from Ratlinghope Church.A fierce storm blew up, snow fell heavily and every- where were deep snowdrifts. His struggle for survival in such Arctic conditions on the Longmynd has made him famous in Shropshire.
